name: Chhath Puja
description: An ancient Hindu Vedic festival dedicated to the Sun God, Surya, celebrating life and prosperity.
significance: Chhath Puja is the most significant festival of Bihar. Devotees offer prayers to the setting and rising sun, expressing gratitude for life and well-being.

name: Sonepur Mela
description: One of Asia's largest cattle fairs, blending spirituality, commerce, and culture.
significance: Held at the confluence of the Ganga and Gandak rivers, Sonepur Mela is historically famous for cattle trade and vibrant cultural activities.

name: Sama Chakeva
description: A folk festival celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters.
significance: Celebrated mainly in the Mithila region, women create clay idols and perform rituals wishing prosperity and happiness for their brothers.

name: Makar Sankranti
description: A harvest festival marking the sun's transition into Capricorn.
significance: In Bihar, the festival is celebrated with traditional foods like Dahi-Chura and sesame sweets, symbolizing prosperity.

name: Bihula-Vishari Puja
description: A prominent folk festival dedicated to the serpent goddess Vishari.
significance: Observed mainly in the Anga region, the festival involves storytelling traditions centered around Bihula and Bala Lakhendra.

name: Madhushravani
description: A festival observed by newly married women in the Mithila region.
significance: Women observe rituals and fasts over thirteen days, praying for a happy and long married life.

name: Pitrapaksha Mela, Gaya
description: A sacred period for paying homage to ancestors in the holy city of Gaya.
significance: Millions of pilgrims perform Pind-daan rituals during this period, seeking peace for their ancestorsâ€™ souls.

name: Buddha Jayanti
description: Celebrates the birth of Lord Buddha with devotion, especially in Bodh Gaya.
significance: Marks the enlightenment and teachings of Buddha, drawing Buddhist devotees from around the world.

name: Saraswati Puja
description: A festival honoring the goddess of knowledge, music, and arts.
significance: Students and educational institutions worship Goddess Saraswati seeking wisdom and learning.

name: Holi
description: The vibrant festival of colors celebrated with folk songs and joy.
significance: In Bihar, Holi features traditional Bhojpuri songs, bonfires, and community celebrations.
